description.narrative: Building the capacity of stakeholders to manage freshwater resources in an integrated manner

Improved water source protection through IWRM Planning and management in Mutsamudu on the island of Anjouan
Outputs
121 Water resource assessment and monitoring systems established
122 Water quality improved through solid waste management and water source protection
123 Reservoir protected from the effects of smallscale farming practices
124 Watershed management plan for Mutsamudu developed
125 Awareness raised on IWRM and catchment management and its contribution to MDGs and gender empowerment

Water resources assessed at identified monitoring points Water resource monitoring operational
Solid waste collection system established and operational
Volumeweight solid waste collected
Volumearea of monitoring point covered in solid waste
Catchment management committee established
Watershed management plan
of training and awareness raising campaigns with gender disaggregated data on water source protection from solid waste and agricultural practice

comment.narrative:
No water quality or quantity monitoring data collected
No collection system amount of solid waste in River Mutsamudu not monitored
No committee exists
No plan exists no data collection or analysis exists to provide basis for management plan
No community engagement on solid waste pollution little awareness observed

Regular water resources monitoring programme established
of households increased serviced by solid waste collection system
30 reduction in solid waste observed at the monitoring point upstream of water supply intake
Committee established with clear TORs and operational
Consultation with landowners and catchment sh completed watershed surveys conducted watershed zone map produced management plan endorsed by stakeholders
Clean up campaigns attended by communities all farmers in the area around reservoirs trained in best farming practice to reduce pollution on reservoir

Water resource assessment initiated and draft reports available Socioeconomic assessment and participatory mapping and zoning initiated and draft reports available A watershed management plan is expected to be completed by September 2015
Consultation on solid waste management is ongoing scenarios for solid waste management have discussed A monthly solid waste cleaning day has been agreed on Additionally through project mobilization several solid waste collection campaigns were held involving the general public schools and military Over 50 of the population of Anjuaon has been sensitized through various channels including outreach activities workshops and media local radio and press
in April 2015 a tripartite partnership with the University of Comoros the Directorate of Water and Energy and Directorate of Environment and Forest was established for water quality monitoring Under the partnership the laboratory of the University of Comoros has been upgraded for water quality monitoring On the otherhand the University is providing ongoing technical support in monitoring and training
In March and April 2015 two training for small scales farmers was held to promote soil erosion control practices Training included onsite demonstration of good practices in which 10 small scale farmers were involved
Two workshops were held on the development of watershed management plans for Mutsamundu river basin and implementation approach agreed on

of households increased serviced by solid waste collection system
30 reduction in solid waste observed at the monitoring point upstream of water supply intake
Committee established with clear TORs and operational
Consultation with landowners and catchment sh completed watershed surveys conducted watershed zone map produced management plan endorsed by stakeholders
Clean up campaigns attended by communities all farmers in the area around reservoirs trained in best farming practice to reduce pollution on reservoir

in April 2015 a tripartite partnership with the University of Comoros the Directorate of Water and Energy and Directorate of Environment and Forest was established for water quality monitoring Under the partnership the laboratory of the University of Comoros has been upgraded for water quality monitoring On the otherhand the University is providing ongoing technical support in monitoring and training
In March and April 2015 two training for small scales farmers was held to promote soil erosion control practices Training included onsite demonstration of good practices in which 10 small scale farmers were involved
Two workshops were held on the development of watershed management plans for Mutsamundu river basin and implementation approach agreed on

description.narrative:
Integrated River basin management plan for the Rio Provaz Basin developed to enable equitable water resources allocation and protection contributing to sustainable economic development public health and environmental protection
Outputs
151 Quality and quantity of water Resources in the Rio Provaz basin assessed
152 Institutional capacity crosssectoral coordination strengthened and decentralized municipal water management fostered through the development and implementation of Basin Water Resources Allocation and Protection Strategy
153 Water pollution reduced through improved wastewater treatment systems piloting ECOSAN wastewater management solid waste collection and disposal and residential sanitation at the poor communities
154 Awareness raised of IWRM at the basin level to strengthen community participation in IWRM and to ensure sustainability

Area surveyed and reported
Water resources level flow and quality data GW resources potential established
Basin water management committee Basin Water Resources Allocation and Protection Strategy
of households using Ecosan

comment.narrative:
No formal inventories of land or water resources or use exists
No regular data collection or quality assurance
No stakeholder consultations on water resources management to date no catchment management committee no water resources management strategies at basin level or national level
No Ecosan technology currently used

100 of catchments area surveyed
Robust quantity and quality data sets collected all major risk type assessed for GW extraction
Stakeholders identified Gender integrated catchment management committees established and operational water resources management strategy developed in a participatory manner and endorsed by the basin stakeholders the process at the demo basin informs the national level IWRM process
100 of constructed Ecosan units still in use at the end of the project of units TBD during the inception phase lessons learned produced aiming for further promotion

Water Resource Assessment and mapping of Rio Provaz Basin was undertaken 100 of the basin has been surveyed and mapped and draft reported submitted Water resource status has been simulated from limited data available
Basin coordination committee established at list 5 meeting held committee members are trained on 7 relevant aspects
On solid waste a large amount of solid waste has been cleared and this continues with an estimated solid waste collection at 20 m3 per month Several awareness campaigns have been carried out to raise awareness on river basin protection at least 50 of the population has been reached
A specialized firm to support on Ecosanitation promotion training and construction has been recruited Work is scheduled to start thereafter

100 of catchments area surveyed
Robust quantity and quality data sets collected all major risk type assessed for GW extraction
Stakeholders identified Gender integrated catchment management committees established and operational water resources management strategy developed in a participatory manner and endorsed by the basin stakeholders the process at the demo basin informs the national level IWRM process
100 of constructed Ecosan units still in use at the end of the project of units TBD during the inception phase lessons learned produced aiming for further promotion

Water Resource Assessment and mapping of Rio Provaz Basin was undertaken 100 of the basin has been surveyed and mapped and draft reported submitted Water resource status has been simulated from limited data available
Basin coordination committee established at list 5 meeting held committee members are trained on 7 relevant aspects
On solid waste a large amount of solid waste has been cleared and this continues with an estimated solid waste collection at 20 m3 per month Several awareness campaigns have been carried out to raise awareness on river basin protection at least 50 of the population has been reached
A specialized firm to support on Ecosanitation promotion training and construction has been recruited Work is scheduled to start thereafter

description.narrative:
Project implemented effectively and efficiently to the satisfaction of partners
Outputs
511 Capable human resources and efficient systems support project implementation
512 Monitoring consultation and advisory mechanisms support project implementation
Project systems work efficiently to provide high quality technical support to countries in IWRM reforms and demonstrations

comment.narrative: No project
Effectively and efficiently implemented project

The Results and Knowledge Management Specialist as part of the Regional Coordination Unit undertook monitoring and support visit to all the countries during the reporting period During the visit project progress and challenges were discussed and recommendation made The Regional Coordination Unit organized a Regional Workshop for all the National Focal Points and the Demonstration Project Manager The UNDP RTA and UNEP Task Manager participated in the workshop The workshop provided unique opportunity for networking monitoring on progress as well as
backstopping
In addition to the regular backstopping by the RTA the visit to Seychelles Demonstration project was undertaken in June 2015 by the UNDP RTA
Effectively and efficiently implemented project

The Results and Knowledge Management Specialist as part of the Regional Coordination Unit undertook monitoring and support visit to all the countries during the reporting period During the visit project progress and challenges were discussed and recommendation made The Regional Coordination Unit organized a Regional Workshop for all the National Focal Points and the Demonstration Project Manager The UNDP RTA and UNEP Task Manager participated in the workshop The workshop provided unique opportunity for networking monitoring on progress as well as
backstopping
In addition to the regular backstopping by the RTA the visit to Seychelles Demonstration project was undertaken in June 2015 by the UNDP RTA

description.narrative:
Protection of a coastal gravel aquifer through integrated land and water management measures water demand management land use flood management demonstrated in the island of La Digue
Outputs
161 Water abstraction reduced through water demand management measures including rainwater harvesting household water tanks to reduce peak water demand wastewater reuse improved metering and tariff reform
162 Groundwater availability and quality improved through improved septic tank management wastewater collection and treatment prevention of seawater intrusion solid waste collection and groundwater recharge

of households business and community buildings with rainwater storage tanks
m3 of reused effluent
reduction in peak water pressure requirements through installation of of household water storage tanks
reduction in leakage in water supply distribution system
Surface water salinity in marsh outlets and GW salinity aquifer recharge capacity of marshland restored
Volume of waste oils and batteries collected

comment.narrative:
Rainwater harvesting practiced only marginally
No wastewater reuse practiced
Limited of households with potable water storage tanks
No leakage detection and reduction programme bulk metering only at water treatment plant
Inflow of seawater at high tide conditions no tidal flaps installed development pressure reduced natural buffering capacity of marshland
Existing collection programmes not effective no collection

100 of targeted buildings using rainwater at domestic and commercial levels
Landscape irrigation schemes using treated wastewater at two hotels
Mandatory installation of potable water storage tanks for all new buildings
10 reduction in system peak pressures
District meters installed and monitored
of leaks fixed m of damaged pipes replaced reduction of m3 of water loss s TBD during the inception
4 tidal flaps installed no seawater flows inland into marshes reinstatement of the marshland
70 of households using collection system

Rainwater harvesting promoted 55 house holds adopted rainwater harvesting with storage tanks at subsidized rates
Consultancy on technical design and costbenefit analysis of waste water treatment was undertaken Hotels were involved and sensitized on the benefits of adoption of the water treatment
Study on the solid waste disposal was completed and part of the recommendations on improvements taken up during the reporting period Through collaboration with the Landscape and Solid Waste Management authority a task was completed on collection of all batteries in the Island Project also supported the regular solid waste collection through provision of more bins for solid waste collection
Several awareness campaigns were held during major national and international water and environment events involving the general public and schools

Mandatory installation of potable water storage tanks for all new buildings
10 reduction in system peak pressures
District meters installed and monitored

description.narrative:
Protection of groundwater resources stabilization of coastal terrains and promotion of productive activities at coastal areas through the integrated planning and management of wastewater collection treatment and reuse demonstrated in Tarrafal in the Island of Santiago Outputs
111 Improved wastewater management systems resulting in more treated wastewater as a alternative water source and reduced untreated wastewater discharge to the ground
112 Increased treated wastewater used for irrigation resulting in less groundwater abstraction and increased crop productivity by the communities
113 Awareness raised on water use efficiency for domestic use as well as tourism sector

Groundwater quality monitoring
m3 of wastewater collected for treatment or of households connected to WWT system
m3 of treated wastewater used for irrigation
of farmers trained for the micro irrigation system with gender disaggregated data
of trees planted as a natural barrier against salinazation
of awareness raising campaigns conducted

comment.narrative:
Limited connection to sewerage system typically 41 currently system operating at 10 capacity
None
None
None
None

Extended sewerage system to 80 of households system operating at its 30 capacity
Xxx TBD during the inception phase
Xxx TBD during the inception phase
Xxx TBD during the inception phase
Xxx TBD during the inception phase

Technical design completed and recommendations available
Selection of household connection has been completed and 580 household mapped for connection to main sewerline This is expected to increase volume of wastewater by 40
A total of 1750 halophite plants were planted to mitigate seashore erosion and salinization
Seven major targeted awareness campaigns have been held reaching out to over 750 people This include two events during a national fair on Environment in 2014 and 2015 in which over 250 persons visited the project promotional stand In February 2014 a 3days participatory IWRM workshop was held raising awareness among key national level senior officials a total of 28 participants representing different departments in the water sector From September to November 2014 awareness raising events on theme water is life were held in Tarraffal involving primary and secondary schools students and teachers Over 200 students were involved and sensitized

Seven major targeted awareness campaigns have been held reaching out to over 750 people This include two events during a national fair on Environment in 2014 and 2015 in which over 250 persons visited the project promotional stand In February 2014 a 3days participatory IWRM workshop was held raising awareness among key national level senior officials a total of 28 participants representing different departments in the water sector From September to November 2014 awareness raising events on theme water is life were held in Tarraffal involving primary and secondary schools students and teachers Over 200 students were involved and sensitized

description.narrative:
Protection of the freshwater lens of Thoddoo Island from salinization and agrochemical pollution with improved drought season aquifer yields
Outputs
131 Sustainable and innovative groundwater extraction system infiltration gallery system established and operational
132 Agricultural practices improved reducing groundwater contamination
133 Sustainable groundwater extraction systems accepted nationally as relevant to island potable water supply and planned for replication nationally
134 Groundwater quality monitoring system established and operational by gender balanced trained locals

Groundwater quality baseline established
of plots receiving water supply from the infiltration gallery system with metering
Reduced groundwater salinity and electrical conductivity
Reduced nitrates and phosphates in GW
Groundwater quality monitoring system established

comment.narrative:
Limited baseline water quality data
No water provided from the system All groundwater extracted from individual wells no metering
Currently elevated salinity and electrical conductivity
Limited data available on GW quality
Non existent

50 wells on faming plots and 50 of household wells monitored
50 of agricultural plots on the island irrigated from the gallery System
Salinity level below 700 µScm 30 reduction from average baseline salinity level
30 reduction from the baseline data
Gender balanced training given to farmers 20 shallow boreholes established for GW quality monitoring

An integrated water supply plan was completed and technical design prepared and approved 100 about 2000 population of the Island will have have portable water supply
Bidding was completed and contractor hired Works was commissioned by the Minister in May 2015
Water planning Committee for the Island was established and actively involved in planning The committee involves the Island Authorities technical departments such as agriculture and fisheries as well as education and community representatives

50 wells on faming plots and 50 of household wells monitored
50 of agricultural plots on the island irrigated from the gallery System
Salinity level below 700 µScm 30 reduction from average baseline salinity level
30 reduction from the baseline data
Gender balanced training given to farmers 20 shallow boreholes established for GW quality monitoring

description.narrative:
The protection and sustainable utilization of the Northern Aquifer of Mauritius demonstrated through the integrated planning and management of wastewater collection treatment and reuse
Outputs
141 Water Resources Assessment conducted to determine and monitor the safe yield and water quality of the aquifer
142 Improved water quality protection of the groundwater and lagoon water quality through improved wastewater treatment and management systems
143 Reduced stress on the aquifer through improved water demand management and dissemination of best practices aiming for replication at the national level and beyond
144 Capacity strengthened and awareness raised among government private sector and civil society for aquifer protection against overextraction and contamination with special focus on climate change and gender empowerment

Water Quality Baseline developed Vulnerability of the aquifer against pollution and extraction assessed
Increased m3 of treated wastewater reused as alternative water resources for recharge irrigation etc
cofin
Impact assessment of the effectiveness of groundwater recharge using the treated wastewater against saline intrusion
Best practices for water demand management captured and disseminated to of stakeholder bodies
of briefings produced by of stakeholders on water resource management and climate changegender empowerment

comment.narrative:
Limited hydrogeological data on the northern Aquifer
1500m3 per day injected in boreholes
Effectiveness of the current practice unknown
Limited awareness of policy makers about the importance to protect groundwater and lagoon
Limited awareness about saving water and polluting activities

Scientific baseline reports on hydrogeological data land use and pollution activities categorized and compiled vulnerability map produced protection measures in place at sensitive areas
2500m3 per day used as alternative water resources irrigation recharge etc
Aquifer effectively protected from saline intrusion using the results of the assessment Salinity monitored
50 policy stakeholders advocating importance of GW protection
35 of public receive best practice guidance on pollution prevention and effective water consumption
100 of IWRM coordination mechanism aware of climate change issues
Gender disaggregated data on water management become available

As regards Output 141 Water Resources Assessment conducted to determine and monitor the safe yield and water quality of the aquifer a consultant was appointed and specifications prepared for the drilling of 45 boreholes and installation of piezometers
Output 142 Improved water quality protection of the groundwater and lagoon water quality through improved wastewater treatment and management systems The Wastewater Treatment Plant at Grand Baie has been operating and at the same time the consultancy services for the detail design for house connections has been awarded It is expected that the house connections will be started in 2016
143 Reduced stress on the aquifer through improved water demand management and dissemination of best practices aiming for replication at the national level and beyond A school competition was launched in May 2015 to raise awareness on water management and enhance the understanding of IWRM in the population
144 Capacity strengthened and awareness raised among government private sector and civil society for aquifer protection against overextraction and contamination with special focus on climate change and gender empowerment This will take place after the results from the drilling and water samples are analyzed

35 of public receive best practice guidance on pollution prevention and effective water consumption
100 of IWRM coordination mechanism aware of climate change issues

description.narrative: To accelerate progress on WSSD targets and IWRM and WUE plans and water supply and sanitation MDGs for the protection and utilization of groundwater and surface water in the participating countries

Limited connection to sewerage system typically 41 currently system operating at 10 capacity
None
None
None
None
IWRM is entrenched in the broader work of national partners
6 SIDS countries develop IWRM plans meeting MDG target 7a
Subsets of the AIO SIDS show demonstrable progress in improving water use efficiency and access to safe drinking water andor basin sanitation thereby making progress on MDG targets 7b or 7c respectively P
Specific improvements in water resources management at 6 national demonstration sites
National interministerial committees support IWRM processes in 6 SIDS by close of project
Mechanisms in place to monitor freshwater resources in 6 SIDS by close of project

comment.narrative:
Limited or no application of IWRM principles or tools and processes at various levels within SIDS
Limited awareness of various stakeholders roles in IWRM
Little or no exchange of experience regarding IWRM and best practices amongst SIDS
2 AIO SIDS countries have national crosssectoral IWRM committees at different levels of deveopment
Limited or in some cases no freshwater resource monitoring systems in place in the 6 AIO SIDS

National partners have knowledge of IWRM concepts and their roles in implementing IWRM and participate in IWRM related networks
National partners are incorporating IWRM concepts and tools into their work at various levels
Successful project demonstrations are replicated through other means
6 AIO SIDS have established interministerial committees managing IWRM processes
6 AIO SIDS employing monitoring framework for freshwater resources and this information informs water management

IWRM demonstration projects are ongoing in all six countries with functional IWRM coordination committees at Basin level Through the multistakeholder plat forms and participatory approach the project has created platform for addressing water challenges and awareness raising effectively raising awareness at national level on benefits of IWRM adoption Following the demonstration project intervention number of gaps have been identified and policy recommendations made

National partners have knowledge of IWRM concepts and their roles in implementing IWRM and participate in IWRM related networks
National partners are incorporating IWRM concepts and tools into their work at various levels
Successful project demonstrations are replicated through other means
6 AIO SIDS have established interministerial committees managing IWRM processes
6 AIO SIDS employing monitoring framework for freshwater resources and this information informs water management

IWRM demonstration projects are ongoing in all six countries with functional IWRM coordination committees at Basin level Through the multistakeholder plat forms and participatory approach the project has created platform for addressing water challenges and awareness raising effectively raising awareness at national level on benefits of IWRM adoption Following the demonstration project intervention number of gaps have been identified and policy recommendations made
